lom:description.lom:string:
"The goal of this course is to provide an introduction to materials science by applying it to the understanding and appreciation of selected objects from art and archaeology. By doing this, the course is intended to introduce students to the language and practice of science, to the methods used to pose and test hypotheses, and to the logic involved in developing theory. The use of art and archaeological pieces as the objects of study will demonstrate the significance of scientific inquiry in other disciplines, such as archaeology, art history, and history
The students are expected to gain an appreciation of the social and cultural significance of various artifacts and objects of art through lectures and classroom discussions. Then the various properties of the objects will considered from a materials science perspective. The objective of such an approach is to highlight the connections between the processing, structure, and properties of materials. Starting from considerations of atoms, crystals, liquids, glasses, polymers, the students will learn about the development of structure through equilibrium, shaping, capillarity, rates of change, etc., and note how the particular structure produces the particular properties of the objects. Structures, characteristics, design, manufacture and use of material objects will be discussed in relationship to art and art history, archaeology, materials conservation and ancient, historic, and modern technology."
